description:
Human papillomavirus 18 (HPV-18) is a DNA virus that belongs to the Papillomaviridae family. It is one of the high-risk HPV types, meaning it is associated with an increased risk of developing certain types of cancer, particularly cervical cancer.

HPV-18 is a small, non-enveloped virus with an icosahedral capsid structure. Its genome consists of a circular, double-stranded DNA molecule, approximately 8,000 base pairs in length. The viral genome encodes several early (E) and late (L) genes, which are responsible for viral replication, transcription, and the production of viral structural proteins.

HPV-18 is primarily transmitted through sexual contact and can infect the basal cells of the stratified squamous epithelium, such as the cervix, vulva, vagina, penis, and anus. The virus can cause the development of precancerous lesions, known as cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), which can progress to invasive cervical cancer if left untreated.

HPV-18 is considered one of the most oncogenic HPV types, meaning it has a higher risk of causing cervical cancer compared to other HPV types. It is often found in combination with HPV-16, another high-risk HPV type, in cervical cancer cases.

Vaccination and regular cervical cancer screening are crucial for the prevention and early detection of HPV-18-related cancers. Ongoing research continues to explore new treatment and prevention strategies for HPV-18 and other high-risk HPV infections.
